instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: Not sure where to start here. <CHIP>U6630</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: Audio Codec <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>, voltage on pins 9, 25 and 46...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message:
Hi. 

pin 9 - 1.816V
pin 25 - 4.49V
pin 46 - 5.03V

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message:
Can you explain why <CHIP>U6630</CHIP> has anything to do with the codec working?

History of the board? <RESISTOR>R6211</RESISTOR>/12, <RESISTOR>R1810</RESISTOR>/11/12/13 checked? Knocked off components around <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: Had checked briefly what was obvious to me on <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> before I posted. And saw someone suggest <CHIP>U6630</CHIP> from a Google search. So I guess I was fishing. This is the same board that I just had the BL issue with <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. Will check your suggestions. Thanks for the help guys.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: Hi... All recommended components to check are good. I did have to replace DZ6700 and DZ6704 because the where both cracked but these are for audio jack. Other then that everything looks OK. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> is the only thing left then, but seeing as there was more physical damage to the board my bet would still be a damaged/knocked off component somewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: Ok... I figured you were going to say that. :) Thanks. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message: So I replaced <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> and audio did start to work. After I shut it down and restarted it the audio did not work at all. I'm guessing that t isn't the chip itself but like you said a component around it because it seems like by heating up the area when I replaced the chip is what made it start working. Tantalum capacitors? Thanks man.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio device detected
threads.message:
More like something that is cracked. I cannot help you find the damaged cap/resistor. Only thing I can say is look closely and measure.

You are sure the complete device is not detected? Also nothing on headphone?
